reviewText: In what other game can you literally take your shoes off, throw them at a monster and kill it? Who throws a shoe? Honestly!\n\nVulture brings the quintessential Roguelike, Nethack to life with an updated user interface and graphics. Roguelike has been a heavily abused buzzword in the gaming industry for the past few years plus. Hey
date:
look! Something random happens in this game...it's a Roguelike!"
No...no it is not. Knock it off you.
That's not to say I don't play many of those games too but this game is more deserving than any other on Steam to be called a true Roguelike.

Vulture isn't perfect and still retains Nethack's learning curve for the uninitiated but more improvements are coming
recommended: including a massive update to the graphics
voteText: music and more. There's also a fine line in Nethack in regards to the "spoilers." I would encourage players to try playing on Wizard Mode before reading the big book of Nethack spoilers.\n\nP.S. You're gonna die...a lot."

reviewText:
Vulture for Nethack makes accessible to the gaming public
one of the most original, challanging, and intriguing games
of all time.

Nethack was originally released in 1987 with ASCII
graphics. In it, the player must traverse scores of randomly
generated dungeon levels in order to locate the Amulet of
Yendor and return it to his Deity's altar on the Astral Plane.
The game is notoriously difficult and has an almost infinite
replay value. However, it's poor graphics and obscure interface
has kept it beneath many gamers' radar.

Vulture has changed nothing about Nethack but the graphics
and interface. The graphics are attractive and set a sort of
Dungeons and Dragons mood. The mouse-driven interface is smoothe
and intuitive, the drop-down menus are self-explanatory and helpful,
and the music, sound-effects, and occasional animations bring the
game to life.

Nethack is now more accessible to the new player, and only the
most die-hard fan of the old ACII graphics is likely to object
to the beautiful improvements that DarkArts Studios has made
to the way this game is played.
voteText: 91 of 104 people (88%) found this review helpful 4 people found this review funny

reviewText:
NetHack itself is cool. And while Vulture adds much-needed graphics to NetHack, it doesn't do that great of a job with the interface.

1. Not all possible commands are exposed, so you still need to know the keyboard controls to NetHack, or at least have a reference
2. The interface is cumbersome to use. If I want to shoot a monster it takes multiple mouse clicks. Something as basic as shooting should be a single click, or keystroke
3. The interface doesn't remind the player of what keystrokes correspond to what commands. That in my opinion is the biggest failure of Vulture. I could tolerate Vulture as a crutch until I learned all the controls. But since Vulture doesn't teach me what the controls are it's not useful for learning purposes.

Vulture is kind of lazy, it's a shell over the controls NetHack already has and does the bare minimum to present those controls. The UI should have been designed independently of whatever the controls are for Nethack.
voteText: 82 of 94 people (87%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Vulture (once called Vultures Eye) is, simply put, a fancy skin for one of the most legendary games ever created, Nethack.

In my opinion, Nethack is the greatest of the second generation roguelikes, and the pinnacle of what it is to be a roguelike. Just a glance at the Nethack Wiki[nethackwiki.com] will show you just how complex this game is. And the random little reactions certain items have, the times you realize some random piece of junk can actually save your life... this is where Nethack really shines. Little things you pick up along the way (and through multiple runs) eventually make you a hardened, if not always successful adventurer. That lizard corpse you carry at all times, that sprig of wolfsbane, the bundle of unidentified wands, it all reminds you of the times you were less cautious, less knowledgeable of this world you are now a part of.

Vulture makes the game incredibly accessible for those with a bit of patience. If you have been at all enamored with any of the titles spawned from the recent resurgence of roguelike games, and are looking for something more substantial, I can wholeheartedly recommend this product.

(Of course, if you feel up to it, you can just dive in to the unaltered game for free. Though be prepared for ASCII.)

reviewText:
I've played this game for nearly four years, on and off, before getting it on Steam when my harddrive died.
This game is not for the casual gamer, or anyone with high blood pressure.

You will laugh, you will cry, and more than anything, you will die a lot. In all of my time playing I've only ascended one time, and only with the help of bones files (random drops from previously slain characters) and thoroughly studying nethack wiki.

I have two tips:
One, start with melee heavy characters like knight, barbarian, or valkyrie. They are much easier to play, before you get used to the trickier classes like wizard and tourist.

And most important... don't get attached to your pets. Ever. It will lessen the pain.

reviewText:
Vulture for Nethack is a great dungeon crawl. You start with a character and class that you choose or via random selection and try not to die! This may sound easier than it is to achieve. The dungeons are brutal. You start with limited equipment and armor . From room to room and level to level you never know what you will encounter. Will it be an easy floor with plenty of shops and money or will you be shot with a wand of death by an unsuspecting gnome lord?

This is a game that makes you use every bit of knowledge and cunning you have just to get from level to level. You are given spells, wands, potions and various other items to try and best every creature and puzzle you encounter. Good luck try not to make your God angry and always remember to post your YASD! (Yet Another Stupid Death)

Overall this is one of the best games I have played in years. It is a game I have come back to over and over. It has massive replay ability. I highly recommend giving it a shot.  Here are a few tips : Always know where your towel is, Never eat while satiated, Dont F with Shopkeepers, And do try not to genocide yourself.

Good luck and Enjoy!

reviewText:
If you ever wanted to try the classic roguelike NetHack but was terrified because of the ASC II graphics and interface, you should try Vulture. Vulture is an graphical interface for NetHack. It makes the game much more user friendly and give you that 90's RPG feel with the isometric visuals.

The goal of the game is to go down 50 floors, find the amulet of Yendor and go back 50 floors to exit the dungeon. NetHack is hard, like really HARD, but with a lot of humour, so you never get too overwhelmed.

There's hundred ways to die in NetHack, and believe me, it's fun discovering them. On my first playthrough I drank water from a fountain, was transformed into a lynx and was killed by monsters spawned from a cursed chest.

If you enjoy pure roguelikes (turn-based) you can't go wrong for U$ 2.99. My only advice is: read the manual (specially chapter 9.2 - interface options) to learn how to properly configure resolution (yes, you can play with true 16:9 aspect ratio), sounds, etc, and know more about the game itself.

reviewText:
Never played NetHack? Well, previously, there was only one excuse for that; aversion to ASCII-based graphics.

Now there is no excuse. You cannot seriously call yourself a gamer until you have played NetHack.

NetHack is a game where experimenting is both rewarding and punishing. To say there are a million ways to die in NetHack is an understatement; you WILL die. A lot. I encourage liberal experimentation for your first hundred or so games. This will result in them being over very quickly, and, as a result, you'll learn 100 ways to die and 100 things not to do.

NetHack is THE quintessential roguelike. Heck, NetHack is the second choice for the very definition of roguelike (the first choice being Rogue itself). It's filled to the brim (and above) with content. Paired with the permadeath that defines roguelikes, this gives NetHack a legitimately enormous replay value.

NetHack is BLOODY HARD. As stated before, you will die. A lot. A whole lot. You have to go down roughly 50 floors, with each and every one teeming with foes that can and (given half a chance) will kill you. Then you have to go back UP those 50 floors. This 100-floor fact gets really scary when you see just how easy it is to die on the first few floors.

That being said, NetHack is also fair. It's been postulated that every game generated is winnable, played by a sufficiently experienced player. There are people that can win many games in a row. Given enough time, you can become one of those people.

Do you, for some reason, not have $3 to pay for this? Google NetHack. There are plenty of ways to play the ASCII version (which, besides graphics, is the exact same thing) for completely free. (The graphics are totally worth it though.)

reviewText: When people talk about Rogue-likes" this is the game that *almost* started it all.  It's effectively the follow-on to the original ASCII "Rogue" game. It's pretty ancient.  A good number of you probably weren't even born when NetHack came out.\n\nHere's the TL:DR version:If you want a VERY in-depth and brutal dungeon exploration game
date: where you will die A LOT
recommended:
then this really is the one you want to play.

Here's the full version:
This is an interface update to a game that's been around (and in almost constant development) since about 1987.

It was
voteText: a top-view text game
helpfulPercent: where a wall might have been expressed with a block: █  and your character was an @.  The floors were all full-stops
votesHelpful: and there were so many key-commands to do things that you just got lost.\n\nVulture for Nethack is a graphical update to the original game. It turns those ASCII characters into isometric graphics
votesTotal: and takes some of those awkward keypress commands and puts them into menus to make them easier to get at.\n\nIf you want some kind of comparison... this is the great
commentsCount: grand-daddy to games like Dungeons of Dredmor. It is far FAR more complex and involved. There are so many more things to do
column18: get killed by.\n\nVulture's graphics are certainly an improvement on the original Nethack (unless you're a purist) but they're not even close to as good as Dredmor's. There's no animation to speak of
column20: and the isometric is a bit icky in narrow corridors - but the strength of this one is the game itself

reviewText:
http://i.imgur.com/2GGegPn.png?1

Give me a break.

Edit:  I appreciate the developer's response and intend to delete this review if/when the problem is fixed.

Edit 2: The specific sprite I originally complained about has been removed, but still I've made a liar of myself and changed my mind.  I think this review deserves to stick around for posterity because the difference between borrowing assets for a project that isn't being charged for (that is to say, previous versions of nethack etc.), and one that is (Vulture for Nethack as released on steam specifically), is an important difference to me, and there are still borrowed (being vaguely euphemistic here) assets in the release of this game as of the time of writing.

A library of sprites comprised largely of images most likely grabbed off of google images without permission and edited is less acceptable when it's in a paid product (this is not an accusation of theft directed at the developer(s) but more an observation of the tilesets ported from previous versions and the fact that they are still present in this one).  I think this version of the game should receive a massive graphical overhaul for that reason alone.

With all that said, I intend for this to be the final edit to this review.  In parting:
http://i.imgur.com/HLZORSP.png?1

reviewText: Nethack. This game means a lot to me. Since I discovered this gem some years ago it has always had something new to show me nearly every time I give it a go. It has been years and I have never ascended but I grow closer everytime I create a character. There is so much to learn in this game and the mouse interaction and menu screens in this version make that a lot easier though at this point I prefer to use the key commands since I know them by heart. This game takes time and patience and is an incredibly deep game. I believe this game has the longest history for development which has been shared among many fans over the years since the 80s. This is the original roguelike" as Nethack refers to its development. This is a "hack" of the original Rogue by way of the "net" when the internet was still in its infancy and only available to those in Universities or those who worked for telephone companies and is still under ongoing development by the community to this day. This interface makes Nethack more user friendly for first time users and may be a good starting point for those interested
recommended: this game has always been completely free and is available at www.nethack.org. Give it a go and if it is your kind of thing then it is sure to keep you busy for years to come."

reviewText: My POV is that we use the term rogue-like/lite only because it was the first. But like most firsts to a thing it was a later version from someone else that did it best, and for me Nethack was that verion. If you played Nethack, this is Nethack. It's just a graphic overlay to Nethack to step beyond the ascii a bit, but it is not it's own game, it is Nethack.\nAnyone who wants to know what it is they are talking about when they use the term rogue-like should for sure either play rogue or better yet play this. I've known plenty of people who've played it, but few who've beaten it. Any game that can be bested  in a single sit, or any regularity by someone is not a very rogue-like game in my eyes. Expect more losses than wins if you choose to delve into these dungeons in seach of the Amulet of Yendor. Games like this are what get the hadrcroe lable from me, and there is a reason they do not make a lot of games like this anymore. It's a more niche audiance that's going to get in for the level of punishment and unfrogiving nature of NetHack. If you thought Dark Souls was hardcore, you might have to alter your scale of assesment if you go a few rounds with this beater of buttocks.\nBTW: As this is NetHack i felt no need to actually log steam hours in this overaly first, due to the countless hours logged over the last few decades already.

reviewText:
Vulture for Nethack is a graphical overhaul of Nethack - essentially larger tiles on an isometric map.

I think anyone who likes RPGs should experience Nethack, and Vulture is the prettiest way to play it. Vulture still has quite a steep learning curve, so patience and a bit of reading will go a long way.

If you haven't played Nethack before getting Vulture first read the Nethack Guidebook ( http://www.nethack.org/v343/Guidebook.html ) to see if Nethack is something you're interested in.
Vulture replaces the sample screenshots in the Guidebook with static isometric tiles (as shown in the Steam store screenshots).
After you've taken the time to familarize yourself with many Nethack commands and been desensitized by frequent horrible death you'll find a game of surprising depth and challenge.

Graphics
Okay - The graphics are of Vulture are (as yet) modest (no animations, modest resolution), but still a big step up from the original ASCII nethack or 2D graphical tiles. I started laughing out loud the first time my wizard (Orcdalf) started hallucinating in game - something that's merely annoying when I'm playing the traditional 2D interface with small tiles seems appropriately ridiculous when playing in isometric Vulture.

My suggestion is to go into the interface options and drop wall opacity down to 0.4 or so, and also switch to half height" walls. This helps to stop the isometric walls obscuring ground objects.

Sound
Poor - The music seems straight out of 1990s midi
date:
and other token environmental and combat sounds are simple.

User interface
Poor - The UI is a work in progress (DarkArts are working on a GUI and graphical overhaul). As is it seems possible to perform most actions in the game with just a mouse - but it's usually much easier using the traditional (esoteric) Nethack keyboard commands.

I did find myself using the mouse menus more than I expected in my test run of Vulture - so they do come in handy (probably as much as the Windows or X versions of 2D Nethack).

Depth
About 50 levels :). Wikis are packed full of spoilers for Nethack or brave (and headstrong) adventurers can persist in discovering new (probably unpleasant) features on every play through..

Replayability
Awesome. With random dungeons and equipment giving a different experience every time
hoursPlayed: and "easter eggs" galore there's always something new in Nethack. Will you have to eat your dog on this adventure?"
votesTotal: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Just in case anybody was unclear, Vulture is literally just a fancy front-end for the game Nethack (which is free).
Vulture is also nearly identical to Vulture's Eye (which is also free).
So if you want to try out the either the original or the isometic modification, you can do that without paying a penny.

Given how many hours I've put into this over the years though, I don't mind handing over a couple of pounds to reward them for making what is probably the best Nethack mod that exists.  It's great for new players, but still completely accomodating for the experienced.

It's a bit rough around the edges, there's no animation or visual effects, and the game just quits out once your run is over.  There's also no SLASH'EM mode!  (Although I guess that's a seperate project, maybe the workshop can take care of it)

All in all, it's a lot of fun, and you could easily play it for over ten years without beating it.

reviewText:
I prefer the ascii original NetHack over this, but this is an exciting way to play the game and adds just enough to warrant a $3 price (which is NOTHING really). The developers seem really active on the forums and they said they will be supporting it. I'm a long time NetHack player (never beaten the game) and am really digging this version. The isometric view and controls take a few minutes to adjust to and there is no option (yet) for ascii style graphics.

The developers have said they are adding Slash'Em for free to the package soon, so that makes it an even sweeter deal.

For those that haven't played NetHack before, I'd recommend getting this and getting the original ascii version and just playing them until your fingers bleed and your friends have all stopped talking to you because all you do is talk about NET HACK.

reviewText: Vulture (now Vulture for Nethack) has been my preferred NetHack front-end since I discovered the game a few years ago. Tried Falcon's Eye, which was a mess and abandoned years ago. Most players haven't EVER 'won' (accomplished The Ascension), but even getting halfway there is a huge accomplishment.  This is a taste of true old school gaming. Be prepared to die - A LOT -, maybe play in exploration mode or Wizard mode and maybe even do some reading at NetHack wiki. The nice thing about NetHack is that no matter how many spoilers" you read

reviewText: I am all for any reason to play NetHack once again so this was a pleasant surprise to see appear on Steam's new releases.  I still love the old ASCII/Tilebased graphics of the original but this is a nice little isometric coat of paint thrown on for the people who absolutely cannot stand ASCII graphics I guess.  Anyone unfamiliar with NetHack should realize this is one of the huge stepping stones that set the foundation for all the roguelikes we see nowadays and often at times the benchmark at what people compare most modern-day roguelikes to. The game is unforgiving, relentless and even in death you will at times find humor in it since there are so many ridiculous ways you can die.  The game just like NetHack closes upon death and the final scoreboard which IS annoying as heck when you want to play it again and you have people messaging you having problems?  it says you're loading up Vulture for NetHack like once every minute or two".  A minor inconvenience that I'm used to.\n\nIn short
date: if you want NetHack on Steam with the graphics presented to you in the screenshots then the price is reasonable considering the hundreds if not thousands of hours I've spent on the original game
recommended: and in those many hours I never really got very far
hoursPlayed: yet still pushed onward hoping I could see something new or die a whole new ridiculous way.  If you have absolutely no clue what NetHack is but enjoy dungeon-based roguelikes then I'd say you owe it to yourself to play this or some iteration of NetHack.  Just do yourself a favor first and go over the manual and study all those commands

and you can't remember when you last saw the sun. You think about your faithful little dog who joined you on your journey to retrieve the Amulet of Yendor.

You feel that eating the little dog was a bad idea. And what's worse is that now you get the distinct impression that every creature you see wants to rip your head off.
Your thoughts are interrupted by the cry of a shrieker
recommended: a sure sign of impending trouble. With a heavy sigh
hoursPlayed:
you ready your sword.
Times are tough."

reviewText:
Nethack is an incredibly difficult tile-based roguelike. The game is always different every time you play, and being a roguelike, death is permanent. Each playthrough tells a tale of how horribly your player character dies, (or lives, if you escape the dungeon, or actually BEAT THE GAME) and because of the random nature of the game, you are going to die in many different sadistic and stupid ways. For instance, see that pretty amulet lying on the floor?  Out of curiousity, you pick it up and wear it. The amulet strangles you to death and you die. Overall, I find this game both very fun and challenging. There are free versions of nethack available in the form of ascii and tiled, top-down versions, so if you're not sure about it, I recommend getting either one of those versions first before playing.

You fall below the bottom of the review!
You die...
Do you want your possessions identified? [ynq] (n) _

reviewText:
I assume if you are viewing this page you already are familiar with Nethack, but if not, let me give you a very brief rundown.

Nethack is a turn-based, extremely difficult, freeware dungeon crawling rpg that came out all the way back in 1987, a direct descendant of Hack, which in turn is a descendant of Rogue (hence the term Rogue-like.) The game can be downloaded here. http://www.nethack.org/

The idea is you need to traverse a dungeon to retrieve The Amulet of Yendor for your deity. Along the way you fight monsters, solve puzzles, and avoid traps.

Does this sound generic? Well, it is the inspration for countless other games, and is far superior to even most modern games, despite its lack of flashy sounds and graphics.

Every game is different. The dungeon and its contents are generated at random. It is extremely unforgiving. There are insta-death items, and beasts that want nothing more than to decorate with your innards. You have no lives. There are no restarts. Once you die, you start from square one in a completely new dungeon. Nethack also has an odd sense of humor. You can eat the corpse of a Werejackal, becoming one yourself, and summon up jackal friends to devour you foes. You can rob a shop the Keystone Kops will persue you. You can Blind a Basalisk with a pie.


Its a graphical version of one of the greatest games ever concieved. I prefer the original ASCII over this but purchased this mainly to track playtime and see another interpretation of what the dungeon looks like.

As another reviewer pointed out, you still need to know the keyboard commands. This makes the learning curve to a new player less steep, but honestly if you never played a rogue-like before I would recommend starting with  Crawl  (also freeware)  http://crawl.develz.org/  . It has a version that is completely playable via mouse, and a very friendly UI.

reviewText: My steam hours will fail to impress upon anyone reading this how much time I actully have in this game and this interface. For anyone who doesn't know the interface is over 12 years old (I beleave, from the Falcons Eye project) It is how I came to play Nethack. After the project got retired by the original creator it became Vulters Eye when picked up again and work was done on a Slash'em interface Vulters claw...which was greatly broken.....I got this soly so i could play Slash'em (gave up like 5+ years ago) and so far it is working wonderfully! I'm very glad to see this up and running again. If you have never played Nethack be warned it is very unforgiving in it's normal mode (you can change it to adventure for a much more relaxed gameplay, just unscored) Slash'em is even MORE so. But if you take the time to play and experiment their is a HUGE amount of playtime awaiting you and you'll be very suprised what you can do (for instince if you're any magic and you've learnt a scroll for a spell you don't have yet....soak a spellbook for a spell you don't like in water <any fountain will do> and write a new book for said scroll you've read with a magic marker...VOILA you now have said spell in learnable form) this is one tiny example of manipulation you can do. There is a lot of twisted and wonderful ways to build your character up. You can train pets/mounts, theres an alchemy system, ways to make rare weapons from normal ones, wishes ect ect ect ad nausium. If you like dungeon crawlers get this game! Though if your a graphics ♥♥♥♥♥ over gameplay...you won't like it lol.

reviewText: I must say that Nethack is one of the greates games I have ever played, I am no Nethack veteran and started playing it on my phone when i first found interest in Rogue-Likes. reviewText: Vulture makes a classic RPG more accessible than ever with 2.5d isometric graphics, true mouse support, cloud saves and scoreboard, and an excellent manual and help menu. reviewText: Edit: It has been pointed out that my complaints for Vulture (after my 1 hour of gameplay) may be incorrect.  Some of the things listed in the comments I thought I had tried and had no success, but I can't go back to check as I no longer have the game.  Please take the comments below into account before deciding on purchase. I stand by my No" recommendation as I still think Nethack is best in it's original form
date:
but take the specific complaints with a grain of salt.

---

As with all graphical interfaces that have been tacked on the top of Nethack
recommended: Vulture suffers from enough flaws to make it unusable for anyone that is familiar with the game.  Several major flaws made this unplayable as a Nethack game:\n1) cannot eat corpses from the floor.  Huge problem as you had to pick them up
voteText:
in order to eat. This is a huge problem as eating then takes may more turns and makes a hard game even more difficult.
2) no way to throw a corpse/tripe to your pet.  This is a must for training.
3) pet is a constant annoyance to what is an otherwise nice mouse-click based movement system.
4) notifications of items on the floor seem to be suppressed
votesHelpful: make it easy to miss things.\n5) graphical icons are never as clear as the original Nethack ASCII characters.  Could eventually learn them
votesTotal: but feel it's not worth the effort at this point.\n\nThese are some of the big annoyances I found in just an hour or so of play.  Having the interface limit my choices was very unworkable.  If you aren't familiar with Nethack
votesFunny: you may not miss the flexibility
commentsCount: but it will still kill you.\n\nI've been playing Nethack off and on for 25ish years.  I've tried a lot of graphical interfaces for it over the years and have been disappointed by all of them.  I was hoping from the positive reviews that this one might work out
column16: but it is still unusable for any serious play.  Not to say it didn't have good points
column17: it does.  The menus are nice
column19: it made some of the meta commands more accessible and the mouse movement is really nice.  Ultimately
column21: deeply rewarding game that if Vulture is the ONLY way you will play it
column22: get it and try it out.  But if you really want to experience Nethack
column23: do it in the original ASCII
column24: it will be well worth your time to learn it."

reviewText:
I would like to comment on the art style/choice used by the developer.

I personally think that the choice is what every fan of the game expected.
It is a good balance between keeping it as old school and retro as possible yet blowing some new life into and bringing it to new generation of players that never played and might not have even heard of Nethack before coming across it here on STEAM.

The developer could have gotten any number or art assets that had all the bells and wistles that comes with new AAA tiltes these days, but that would have not been Nethack then, and I think many of the old school fans would have seen and felt that to have been the wrong choice.

So to me the execusion has been successful, and true to the game that we all has come to love.

I think even the developers of Nethack would be proud of what has been done here.
The product is going to again build many fond memories for many gamers young and old.

reviewText:
As a huge fan of the *free* game called Nethack, I cannot reccommend Nethack Vulture on Steam.  Vulture just adds a 3D isometric view to the existing game, and a horribly ugly one at that. I highly recommend getting the latest version of Nethack which can be downloaded for free at http://www.nethack.org  - It even comes with good 2D tilesets (just launch NetHackW.exe instead of Nethack.exe).

Nethack is an amazing game, and I don't want the bugs and shoddy quality of Vulture to drive anyone away from trying the original version of the game.

I only bought Vulture so I could write this review. This is also my first review.


PS:  Just in case you didn't get the idea from the previous reviews, Nethack is HARD. That game held my attention for 6 years, not bad for a game that came out in 2003. And yet I have never beaten the game, in fact I've never made it past the first 10%. My Dad is a programmer, so of course he hacked himself infinite wishes and HP and STILL got stuck 50% of the way through the game! (Specifically, he got surrounded by death ray resistant creatures on a no teleport/no dig hell level and couldn't hit with silver weapons since he was a monk trained only in barehanded combat. Though now that I think about it he could have made it if he had wished for a humanoid pet and had given it a silver weapon...) For a sense of scale, I've had Dark Souls 2 for three months and already beat NG++.

reviewText: I'm not pleased to my purchase. I also believe that you may play NetHack with Vulture for free legally through the wonders of internets.\n\nFirst of all I used to play a lot of ADOM. I learned all of it's quirky commands and got used to the ASCII interface. That was back in the day when all I got was time. I never tried NetHack though and thought it would be a fun little attraction for my coffee breaks. Apparently it's a matter of taste but I felt that this Vulture interface looks horrible and while you may play it by using mouse only it doesn't feel very accurate. The viewing point is also in such a weird angle that it hurts my brain. Basically NetHack is one of THE original roguelikes and meant to be super hard and unforgiving. There's tons of loot and equipment, skills, pets, monsters and everything you could damand from a roguelike game. The story is somewhat typical for RPG's: There's this item that you need and you also have to bring it back from the dungeon. Take a look of the screenshots for the game, buy it if you are accustomed to NEtHack and love it to death already (even just to support the devs) but I can't recommend this one for any new players since it's a quite overwhelming task to conquer this old beast.

reviewText:
I love randomized dungeon hacking games, but this one left a bad taste in my mouth.  I admit I wasn't previously experienced with NetHack, but I was expecting something a bit more modern and, well, playable.  Be warned that this game has a steep learning curve, a lot of confusing options, and very basic sound and graphics.  Although I haven't played for very long, it simply wasn't very fun and unfortunately I can't recommend it.

PROS
+ Potentially endless replayability
+ Over a dozen character classes
+ Dirt cheap

CONS
- Clunky menus and virtually no main menu
- Confusing options
- STEEP learning curve
- Navigating levels is a chore (MOVE IT HORSIE!)
- Requires significant time investment to be fun
